summary: Leo Cherne was the president of the Research Institute of America (RIA). The CIA used RIA and Cherne to provide cover for CIA operatives. This involved creating employment backstories and potential overseas cover for agents. Cherne's name appears in connection to a request from the House Select Committee on Assassinations (HSCA), indicating that he was a person of interest during the investigation into the JFK assassination. The documents suggest that the HSCA was interested in Cherne's connections and any information the CIA might have had on him.
significance: Leo Cherne's significance in the JFK context stems from his role as the president of the Research Institute of America (RIA), which the CIA used to provide cover for its operatives. The HSCA's interest in Cherne suggests a potential link, however indirect, to individuals or organizations involved in the assassination, warranting further investigation into his activities and connections with the CIA.
